trial_identification.studytitle: Peak torque and knee kinematics during gait after eccentric isokinetic training of quadriceps in healthy subjects
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Peak torque and knee kinematics during gait after eccentric isokinetic training of quadriceps in healthy subjects

conditioncode.conditioncode2: Normal musculoskeletal and cartilage development and function

interventions.interventions: The bilateral isokinetic eccentric training (30º/s) of the knee extensors was: 3 set of 10 maximal contraction; 2 times a week for 6 weeks

primaryOutcome.outcome: The knee extensor torque in the nondominat limb was measured by isokinetic dynamometer before and after protocol training
The flexion/extension and varus/valgus knee movements before and after training measured by electrogoniometer

secondaryOutcome.outcome: The hamstrings/quadriceps (H:Q) ratio was calculed (hamstrings peak torque/quadriceps peak torque X 100) before and after protocol training

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Healthy and active male subjects without any musculoskeletal injuries or symptoms or equilibrium disorders
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: No involved in other training program to improve the muscle force or knee pain

sponsorship.primarysponsoraddress: Rua Alvarenga Peixoto, 331 apto 42 - Cidade Jardim - Sao Carlos, SP CEP. 13566-582

fundingsource.fundingname: Fundacao de Amparo a Pesquisa do Estado de Sao Paulo

secondarysponsor.sponsoraddress: Departamento de Fisioterapia Rod. Washington Lu?s, km 235, Monjolinho, Sao Carlos, SP CEP. 13565-905

ethicsAndSummary.summary: Changes in the gait pattern may occur as a consequence of joint tissue derangement, knee joint swelling, weakness of the quadriceps femoris muscle, or muscle inhibition due to pain. In a recent study11, where we applied eccentric isokinetic training of the quadriceps muscles in subjects submitted to anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) reconstruction, the knee extensor torque and flexion/extension range of motion during gait increased significantly after training. However, an unexpectedly increased valgus, most pronounced during the swing phase, as well as an increased valgus/varus range of motion, which may imply adverse effects on the knee, were also observed in the ACL reconstructed knee when compared with the healthy untrained knee. Hence, the mechanisms involved in the increased valgus, as well as its functional and clinical implications, needs clarification before eccentric training can be generally recommended for rehabilitation and sports activities. Thus, this study had the objective of evaluating the effects of eccentric isokinetic training on the strength of the extensor and flexor muscles of the knee, and the sagittal and coronal knee movements during gait, in healthy male subjects
ethicsAndSummary.publication: SANTOS, HH; ÁVILA, MA; HANASHIRO, DN; CAMARGO, PR; SALVINI, TF. Efeitos do treino isocinético excêntrico dos extensores do joelho sobre a razão I/Q. XII Congresso Brasileiro de Biomecânica, Sao Pedro, SP, 2007.
